metadata.title: Proposed Resumption of Surgery Algorithm Following the Corona Virus SARS-CoV-2 Pandemic

body_text.text: The novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) pandemic has crippled vascular surgery practices around the world with almost four million cases and over 260,000 deaths as of May 6, 20201. In order to preserve hospital resources including personal protective equipment and ventilators as well as to “flatten the curve” of exposure of patients and healthcare providers to COVID-19, most centers have imposed limitations on elective/scheduled surgical practices2. For vascular surgeons, this may include limiting procedures such as peripheral arterial disease with claudication, asymptomatic carotid artery disease, small aortic aneurysm, superficial venous disease, and most dialysis access. Many vascular procedures however are urgent, with delay in treatment resulting in loss of limb or life. In the aftermath of such a global dampening of practice, resumption of surgical services needs to be thoughtful in order to optimize the care of patients and minimize risk to the healthcare team. A recent joint statement from the American College of Surgeons, American Society of Anesthesiologists, Association of Perioperative Registered Nurses, and the American Hospital Association suggests this return of service should not occur until several factors are met, including a sustained reduction in the rate of new regional COVID-19 cases for 14 days and the availability of both PPE and COVID-19 testing3. Additionally, they recommend case prioritization to ensure those patients with the highest needs will be treated first, although they don’t specifically comment on these cases, deferring instead to local committees created to adjudicate all cases.
Matthew R. Smeds and Sameer Siddiqui

Legend: Management of patients during COVID-19 peak pandemic - Patients are sorted based off acuity of diagnosis (numerically 1-3) and health status of the patient (a: healthy, b: unhealthy). Those in tiers 1and 2 are delayed if at all possible while those in tier 3 are performed. HOPD = Hospital Outpatient Department, ASC = Ambulatory Surgery Center.

FIGREF1.text: Figure 2: Resumption of Surgery Algorithm. Legend: Resumption of surgery algorithm based off acuity of case and health status of the patients. The healthiest patients with the highest acuity should be preferentially scheduled in the inpatient setting while those with low acuity should be scheduled in outpatient setting. HOPD = Hospital Outpatient Department, ASC = Ambulatory Surgery Center
